RespTxt: 0-10 degrees, not favorable, don't care too much for the person
QuestionTxt: I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I will use something we call the feeling thermometer and here is how it works: I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one. If you do recognize the name, but you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person, you would rate the person at the 50 degree mark.... (President) Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: A post election survey with re-interviews of 1989 (84%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted November 07, 1984-January 25, 1985.

(Now, I'd like to again rate your feelings toward some people, with one hundred meaning a very warm, favorable feeling, zero meaning a very cold, unfavorable feeling, and fifty meaning not particularly warm or cold. If you have no opinion of never heard of that person or organization, please say so.)...Ronald Reagan
StudyNote: National registered likely voters are registered voters who voted in the 2000 Presidential election/were ineligible/too young to vote or who didn't vote in the 2000 election but did vote in the 2002 Congressional election

RespTxt: 0-10 degrees, not favorable, don't care too much for the person
QuestionTxt: I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I will use something we call the feeling thermometer and here is how it works: I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't care too much for the person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't have to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.... (President) Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SubPopulation: Asked of those in the Long Form (98%)
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: The respondents were originally interviewed in the pre-election study of 2241 adults conducted September 5, 1984-November 5, 1984. QuestionTxt: I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I will use something we call the feeling thermometer and here is how it works: I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't care too much for the person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't have to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.... (President) Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SubPopulation: Asked of those in the Long Form (98%)

QuestionTxt: (Now I am going to read to you some reforms and innovations that have been proposed to make democracy work better and to make the government work more in the interests of the whole country and ask you to rate each of these on the zero to one hundred scale, where now one hundred means that you are very favorable to it, zero means you are very unfavorable to it, and fifty means that you're neutral. Again you can use any number from zero to one hundred, the higher the number, the more you favor the proposal. And now some proposals that change the effect of money on decisions.)... Bring back the Fairness Doctrine, which was repealed in the Reagan era, to give fair time for competing views
SubPopulation: Asked of Form A half sample
SourceDoc: Americans Talk Issues #22--Improving Democracy in America
StudyNote: The survey was conducted by Market Strategies and Greenberg-Lake

If I name a person you don't know too much about, just tell me and we'll go on to the next one.)...Ronald Reagan

RespTxt: 0-10 degrees, not favorable & don't care too much for the person
QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. You would rate the person at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one.)... Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: A post-election survey with re-interviews of 1775 (87%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted November 8, 1988-January 30, 1989.

QuestionTxt: (Now we'd like your views on some political leaders and groups. Please say whether your overall opinion of each of the following is very favorable, mostly favorable, mostly unfavorable, or very unfavorable.)...Ronald Reagan
StudyNote:
2146 respondents were interviewed online, and 461 by telephone. 
Interviews were conducted both online using a self-administered design and by telephone using live interviewers. All interviews were conducted among participants in AmeriSpeak, a probability-based panel designed to be representative of the national U.S. adult population run by NORC at the University of Chicago. Panel participants without Internet access were interviewed via telephone by professional interviewers under the direction of NORC. NORC¿s AmeriSpeak Panel provides a representative panel of civilian, non-institutional adults (age 18 and over) living in the United States.

QuestionTxt: (Do you think the next President of the United States, during the first year of their administration, should agree to meet with the leaders of Iran, Syria, Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea, without any preconditions, in order to bridge the gap that divides our countries? Or do you think the next president should not promise to meet with the leaders of these nations without first knowing their intentions because that could make the situation even worse, and these nations could be using us for propaganda purposes? Which statement do you agree with more?...Yes, next president should meet with them, no, next president should not promise to meet with them) During Monday's (July 23, 2007) Democratic Debate, Barack Obama was asked that question. Obama said quote I would. And the reason is this: the notion that somehow not talking to countries is punishment to them, which has been the guiding diplomatic principle of this administration, is ridiculous. Ronald Reagan and Democratic presidents like JFK (John F. Kennedy) constantly spoke to Soviet Union because they understood we may not trust them and they may pose danger to this country, but we had the obligation to find areas where we can potentially move forward. Does this make you more or less favorable to Barack Obama?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable

QuestionTxt: (Do you think the next President of the United States, during the first year of their administration, should agree to meet with the leaders of Iran, Syria, Venezuela, Cuba and North Korea, without any preconditions, in order to bridge the gap that divides our countries? Or do you think the next president should not promise to meet with the leaders of these nations without first knowing their intentions because that could make the situation even worse, and these nations could be using us for propaganda purposes? Which statement do you agree with more?...Yes, next president should meet with them, no, next president should not promise to meet with them) During Monday's (July 23, 2007) Democratic Debate, Barack Obama was asked that question. Obama said quote I would. And the reason is this: the notion that somehow not talking to countries is punishment to them, which has been the guiding diplomatic principle of this administration, is ridiculous. Ronald Reagan and Democratic presidents like JFK (John F. Kennedy) constantly spoke to Soviet Union because they understood we may not trust them and they may pose danger to this country, but we had the obligation to find areas where we can potentially move forward. Does this make you more or less favorable to Barack Obama?...Much more favorable, somewhat more favorable, somewhat less favorable, much less favorable
SourceDoc: Mark Penn Digital Polling Data Collection and Oral History, GW Libraries, The George Washington University
StudyNote: This survey was conducted on behalf of Hillary Clinton. These data have been made available with the support of the Society of Presidential Pollsters and the Special Collections Research Center, George Washington Libraries and Academic Innovation, The George Washington University. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for access to materials in the Mark Penn Digital Polling Data Collection and Oral History. Speccoll@gwu.edu

RespTxt: 0-10 degrees, not favorable, don't care too much for the person
QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using this feeling thermometer. You may use any number from 0 to 100 for a rating. Ratings between 50 and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel too favorable toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one. If you do recognize the name, but don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person, you would rate that person at the 50 degree mark.)... Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: A post-election survey with re-interviews of 1408 (87%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted November 4, 1980-February 7, 1981.

Ratings between 50 and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel too favorable toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one. If you do recognize the name, but don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person, you would rate that person at the 50 degree mark.)... Ronald Reagan. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: A post-election survey with re-interviews of 1408 (87%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted November 4, 1980-February 7, 1981.

RespTxt: 0-10 degrees--Not favorable, don't care too much for the person
QuestionTxt: (I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using this feeling thermometer. You may use any number from 0 to 100 for rating. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel too favorable toward the person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one. If you do recognize the name, but don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person, you would rate the person at the 50 degree mark.)... Ronald Reagan
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: The respondents were originally interviewed in the pre-election study of 1614 adults conducted September 2, 1980-November 3, 1980.
